text: The morning had arrived grey and indifferent, as most mornings did in that part of the country.
It was, in every outward respect, an ordinary house â€” and yet there was something about it that seemed to invite a second look.
The lamp in the window had gone out sometime before dawn, and no one had come to relight it.
She had left behind only a small collection of letters, tied with ribbon that had once been blue.
That such a thing could be permitted to pass without remark, in a city that considered itself civilised, was a fact that spoke poorly of its inhabitants.
The spring had arrived early that year, and with it a lightness that seemed to settle over the whole valley without warning.
The evidence, taken together, pointed in one direction only.
By nightfall, the house was still, and the only sound was the slow, patient ticking of the clock in the hall.
The children remembered that summer for the rest of their lives.
And so the matter came to rest, as most matters do, not with a resolution, but with a slow fading into silence.
